title: 110_hr1944
content: The Act titled "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" amends Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new subchapter for screening, rehabilitation, and treatment for traumatic brain injury. The Secretary is required to establish a screening program for veterans eligible for hospital care, medical services, and nursing home care to screen for symptoms of traumatic brain injury. A report must be submitted annually to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs with information on the number of veterans screened, prevalence of symptoms, and recommendations for improving care. The Secretary is mandated to establish a screening program for veterans to detect symptoms of traumatic brain injury. A comprehensive long-term care program for post-acute traumatic brain injury rehabilitation is to be developed, including residential, community, and home-based components. Care will be provided at four designated polytrauma network sites for eligible veterans. Veterans eligible for care under the program must have served in combat operations post-Persian Gulf War, have moderate to severe traumatic brain injury, and require assistance with daily activities. The Secretary is required to submit annual reports to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary is mandated to establish traumatic brain injury transition offices at Department polytrauma network sites to coordinate healthcare and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. Annual reports containing program operation details, number of veterans served, and program costs must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary is required to establish traumatic brain injury transition offices at Department polytrauma network sites to coordinate healthcare and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. These offices can arrange for health-care and services through cooperative agreements with public or private entities that have neurobehavioral rehabilitation programs. Additionally, the Secretary is to establish and maintain a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry for individuals who served in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom and exhibit symptoms. The Secretary is required to establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry for individuals who served in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom and exhibit symptoms. This registry includes relevant medical data and other information with the individual's permission or if the individual is deceased. The Secretary can include information in the Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry with the individual's permission or if the individual is deceased. Individuals listed in the Registry will be notified of significant research developments on the health consequences of military service in Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom theaters of operations. Subchapter IX of title 38, United States Code, includes screening, rehabilitation, transition offices, and a registry for traumatic brain injuries. The Secretary must implement these requirements within 180 days of the enactment of the Act.
